Review Text: A very beautiful place. This month, a beautiful mountain range is visible from afar, which is full of water. This place makes you feel very relaxed in the evening.. If you also visit Udawalawe, do not miss this place....

Review Title: Beautiful atmosphere up at the calm lake and wild water spectacle just below the dam lock! Very impressive contrast
Review Text: Sunrise and sunsets are picturesque when crossing this dam. You can watch brave fishermen at the water lock

A place where the sky meets horizon. Endless blue waters and green trees add another level of beauty. The breeze coming from the reservoir adds calmness to my mind. In the morning cold mist take over makes it scenic.
If you do the safari at udawalawe you will cross the dam and see the massive expanse of water and the run off spectacularly flowing over big boulders creating lots of white water
Awesome scenic view both sides of the dam.Could spot animals for water in the evening.Best place for some great photo shots.Highly suggested spectacular drive through in Udawalwe.
beauty full water tank surround by mountains. Beauty full view can see the eagles and  other fishing birds around that lake

Review Title: Expansive dam for Udawalawe National Park
Review Text: This dam is on the way to the entrance to the Udawalwa National Park.  It is impressively long with great views.  We even saw an elephant on an island near the dam!

Review Title: Scenic Drive Overlooking an Expanse of Pure Water
Review Text: Scenic Drive! I drove along the 4-kilometer-long Uda Walawe dam on 26th November 2019, stopping at interesting locations to take photographs.  A two-lane road runs over the embankment of the dam, built across Walawe Ganga (river).  The 268 million cubic metres of water impounded by the dam provide irrigation facilities to 23600 hectares at both left and south banks of Walawe Ganga.  Two hydro-electric power plants installed at the head of the left and right bank canals generate 6 MW of electricity. The view across the dam is scenic, extending over to the distant hills beyond. The dam incorporates five spill gates on the left end. At the time of my visit, one of these was partially open with water gushing out over its spillway.  Visitors are not permitted to go downstream to watch this phenomenon as it is not considered safe. In addition to the gated spillway, the two power plants and the right and left bank canal outlets, there is a natural spillway, 366 metres long, built at the leftmost end of the dam to protect it against an unusually heavy flood.  The power station near the left bank power plant serves to connect the power plants into the national grid.  on that clear day when we drove over the dam, we enjoyed its large expanse of waters and the scenery extending up to the hills beyond.  We saw some waterfalls too in the distance.
this is the longest dam in srilanka. it is 4 km length and it was built in more than 40 years ago. sometimes wild elephants comes close to the dam to eat some fruites from thepeople.

Its a good place to spend sometime on the way to Udawalawe but not worth considering as a separate activity/ sightseeing location. We stopped for a while simply because it was on our way and we had time to spare. It was pleasant but no different from the surrounding places.
It's very big and you'll see it on the road to Udawalawe . I can't imagine why anyone would wish to visit it.
Freezing view with nature and elephants near main road. Eye catching colors. 4 km long drive start to end.
As the area was experiencing a period of drought the entire area was open with lots of wild animals coming to the remaining water
oh! so nice i like this butty in this place when the dam is opened they took me for the time when the dam is opened because of that i got the chance to feel that experience also
Beautiful to see all the wildlife - especially in the early evening! Great place to watch the sun go down!
Something to view for tourists to Udawalawe, this great collection of freshwater.   On the other side, the locals enjoy a bath in the flowing river among the rocks.   Popular with locals

When entering to the Udawalawe park we are going through the dam. It's not a lot more impressive tourist attraction but if you are travelling in the evening this place gives you a scenic view with the lake. The air flow was heavy when driving through and some times you would be able to see elephants coming near to the nest.

Udawalawa dam was constructed across the Walawe river to construct  Udawalawa reservoir. It is sutuated just 5 km from udawalawa junction towards Thanamalvila. The Thanamalvila B427 road runs along the dam. So this could be the most seen reservoir in Sri Lanka. Wow! The surrounding is always breathtaking and very dynamic. During dry season the water levels are very low due to lack of rain. On one side, there is deep bule waters of the reservoir with the mountainous backdrop and on the other side the low land is blanketed with evergreen lush greenery. In the evening you can easily spot some elephants in the reservoir. It is worth spend at least few minutes there.

Wow what a place to be in the morning or evening as it is great place to see the surrounding area as the view is great. in the evening you can spot elephants whom come to drink and one was their near the road.

The dam is a good viewing point over the Uda Walawe forest. One can see the sunset and even see elephants near the water's edge. There is one bull elephant that comes close to the road looking for treats from visitors
To be seen as part of a wider visit to the National Park. Occasionally see and c elephant or two taking water. The reservoir was very low when we passed by.
A staggeringly large reservoir if you are lucky elephants can be seen going down for drink from the main road

We enjoyed senic views as we crossed the dam to visit the Udawalawe National Park. The water was at a unusally low level for the time of year due to lack of rain. We saw elephants around the water edge at a distance.
Once you are on the road it's one of the most spectacular sceneries. Two types of landscapes can be noticed. When the dam is filled with water or when it is really dry

The road takes you over the head of this large dam where you have great views of the national park from it's elevated position.  There is always an elephant by the fence, and cars frequently stop to take photographs. The water was very low when we travelled at the end of August

We were there on our way to the National park. The dam is so high, you travel on it and you feel the strong breeze passing from one side of the dam to the other. Surrounding mountains far away adds a beautiful touch to the scenic view.

On your drive from Colombo to visit the Udawalawe National Park you pass through this massive agricultural dam over the Walawe river.The Udawalawe tank forms one border of the park , providing water for the animals. If you are lucky you might see one elephant hanging around the electric fence along the dam which prevents them from foraging on the sugar cane fields across.Please DO NOT FEED THIS ELEPHANT.

This is a very long dam! It is about 5 kilometers long. When you drive along or spend time on the dam, you would see the Udawalawe National Park with animals like deer and elephants. There is a famous elephant who use to visit the dam and expect food from people pass by; however, the authorities strongly discourage feeding this particular elephant (may be because of a recent incident with a drunk fool who almost got himself killed by the elephant by approaching in a very idiotic manner making the elephant nervous). The wind that flows above the dam is very strong; especially when you pass this place by a Safari jeep early  in the morning, it's a unique feeling which would only experience at this place. Compared to the other tourist attractions locations, this area consists of many honest people who wouldn't try to rip off visitors; rather we noticed that many people try to be satisfied with the good feedback they get in return for their honesty and good service. Therefore, I would recommend people to visit this place!
